The Government's preferred position is for the Inspector-General to retain the grievance function, but for that function to be very clearly delineated from the Inspector-General's other functions; for the Inspector-General to act in a more adjudicative manner in relation to staff grievances; and for the Inspector-General to be given a determinative power. We believe this approach is more consistent with the role envisaged by Mr Justice Hope for the Inspector-General. The deficiencies that arose in the cases of the complainants arose not because of the involvement of the Inspector-General per se, but because of the constraints under which the Inspector-General operated, some limitations in the mode of operation he adopted and the refusal of some of the complainants to accept his conclusions and recommendations.

The Government agrees with the Commissioners that a move to a more adjudicative process for resolving grievances is necessary, but considers this role should be performed by the Inspector-General, who already possesses the statutory power to do so, rather than the AAT. The Inspector-General already has the flexibility to adopt more adjudicative processes in those grievances where it is appropriate, and has experience and knowledge of the workings of ASIS which will both assist, and be assisted by continued involvement with grievances. The Government has never envisaged a role for the AAT in the resolution of staff grievances within the intelligence community, and believes such a role is more appropriately performed by the Inspector-General, operating under modified procedures, and with a limited determinative power in relation to compensation and reinstatement following unfair dismissal.

I also note that on 6 April 1995 Mr Ron McLeod took up the position of Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. He is a senior public servant with particular depth of experience in defence and public administration. He was formerly Deputy Secretary, Budget and Management, in the Department of Defence and, more recently, headed the team that reviewed the Public Service Act.

It is appropriate to comment at this point on the findings of the Commissioners in relation to the complainants. As I have indicated, the second volume of the classified Report will not be tabled, for reasons of national security and privacy. However, the Commissioners make some comment on the cases in their summary Report, which has already been tabled. They note that there had been significant shortcomings in the treatment of two former officers and the wife of one of those former officers by ASIS management. The Commissioners also found that the wife of one of the former officers is entitled to an apology from ASIS for the stress and hurt caused by her treatment. The Government accepts these findings. In fairness to ASIS management, it needs to be pointed out that to the extent that ASIS's actions with regard to the complainants were found to be deficient, those actions were influenced by ASIS's legitimate concern with secrecy and not motivated by malice. This, of course, does not justify those actions, nor does it ease the suffering of those who were affected. The Director-General of ASIS will make a formal apology to the wife of the former officer, and I join with him in this apology.

Set against these findings, the Commissioners also found that the complainants had no justification whatsoever for their disclosures of sensitive information about ASIS, in view of the solemn and binding commitments of confidentiality they had given. The complainants have put forward the argument that they had no alternative but to make the disclosures they did in order to have their cases heard. This is not true. Despite procedural flaws in the former Inspector-General's handling of some of the cases, his conclusions and recommendations were nevertheless reasonable. The Government cannot be held to account for the complainants' refusal to accept those conclusions. Nor can the disclosures or purported disclosures of sensitive details of ASIS operations, in clear breach of confidentiality undertakings, in any way be excused. In any case, the former officers' grievances concerned deficiencies in administration rather than operations. Finally, there can be no justification, under any circumstances, under any definition of public interest, for making allegations which are known to be untrue.

The Commissioners suggested that, in relation to three of the complainants, considerations of general justice and fairness might warrant an award of compensation, although they also note that the amount of any compensation should be discounted to some degree by the complainants' breaches of confidentiality. The Commissioners made a more specific recommendation in relation to a fourth complainant. The Commissioners judged that it was not within their terms of reference to recommend an amount of compensation to the first three complainants. Therefore, the Government has agreed to set up a process of arbitration to make binding determinations on compensation and other issues arising from the complainants cases. That arbitration process will begin soon, and we expect it to be finalised as quickly as possible. Once that is done, the Government hopes to close the book once and for all on these cases.

As will be apparent from the Report that I am now tabling, many of the public allegations that have been levelled against ASIS—such as rogue activities or bumbling incompetence—are simply not borne out by the facts. ASIS does well the job it was established to do, and is firmly under the control of the Government. The arrangements for its accountability are effective. The Commissioners have made suggestions for enhancing and widening the arrangements for accountability—not as a response to disorder, but as improvements to already satisfactory arrangements which are warranted by changed circumstances. The Government broadly accepts these proposals as positive and useful.

ASIS is well-managed in the performance of its primary task. But its internal organisation and management has at times in the past experienced problems as a result of an internal culture that places a high premium on secrecy and loyalty. These problems unfortunately led in some cases to the inappropriate treatment of some individuals. Those events were unfortunate for all concerned and I do not seek to justify them.

Steps are in hand to change management practices as a matter of priority, including changes to the arrangements for internal review of grievances. There is every indication that the current ASIS management at the most senior levels recognises the need for change and has already embarked on that path. Improvements to the mechanisms for external review of ASIS staff grievances, including the role of the Inspector-General, are also in hand.

Finally, the Government reaffirms the need for secrecy in ASIS's activities, and will take the necessary steps to improve its ability to deter and prevent, in the national interest, the disclosure of sensitive details of ASIS operations. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to speak for long as the government has chosen to intrude upon the Senate's estimates time to deliver a statement today rather than on a day for government business, and also because I think that some of the issues of substance in terms of the reforms that have been proposed are more properly addressed by the shadow foreign minister or the shadow Attorney-General. I want to raise what I think is the substantial issue that the minister avoids, and that is the issue of government responsibility and ministerial responsibility.

PARA.TAB: Whenever there is a problem, it is always the fault of someone else: it is either the journalists who have been irresponsible or it is the bureaucrats who have failed—anyone other than the minister who is responsible for the administration of the portfolio. In the case of ASIS the responsible minister is the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans. Many of the problems in ASIS had been brought to his attention and his failure to act in some way—in considerable ways, it might be argued—has led to where we are today.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is the case, why wasn't I criticised by the commissioners?

—We listened to you; you listen to us. In recent times the management of intelligence matters in this country has been a national embarrassment. What we have been reading in the press in the last week or two has been a national disgrace. It has embarrassed all Australians. Secret intelligence matters are under the administration of government, and government must take responsibility when they go wrong. I am in the comfortable position, I readily concede, where I do not know whether any of these allegations are true or false, but goodness knows what the attitude of the government of the United States or the government of the United Kingdom must be when they read the sorts of statements that have appeared in the press in this country in the last week or two.

PARA.TAB: It is elementary that, in intelligence matters, reciprocation requires that secrets be kept secret. If there is a failure—or an almost total breakdown as is being alleged here—of that security structure, it is highly embarrassing for this country and for all Australians. The government must take responsibility for it. There is no-one else who takes responsibility for it. Whether it is the systems that are put in place, the administration of those systems, the structure of the D-notices, or whatever the detail may be, if it fails and it embarrasses this country it is the government that must take responsibility. If it relates to ASIS it is the foreign minister who must take responsibility.

It is astonishing that, despite the fact that ministers say, `We will neither confirm nor deny', two ministers have been quite ready to enter into this debate. Extraordinarily, when the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, was in Manila he said, `I cannot comment on these security matters', but then decided he would weigh into the debate. He started speculating what the effect would be on our trade relations if the allegations were true. All that did was compound the issue and further embarrass Australia.

It might be said that perhaps he is a minister of less experience than the foreign minister, but the foreign minister did it in this chamber in answer to a dorothy dixer. He wrote the question, which was asked by Senator Murphy, and he started to answer it by saying what they always say: `That is a tradition that I intend strictly to observe,' and, `I will neither confirm nor deny it.' But then he said, `In general terms, there are a few things I would like to say about it: I can assure you that, if we have security arrangements with the United States, we get all the information, and there is no information that we do not have access to.' So he contributed to the debate as to what is—or what may be—the security arrangements between Australia and other countries. These ministers cannot even abide by the terms that they set themselves, the strictures that have been traditionally imposed upon all ministers. They have contributed to the public speculation that has so embarrassed this country in recent times.

The problems that are addressed by the Samuels report are, I presume, unrelated to the issues of recent days, and I guess whether the issues of recent days are going to lead to another inquiry depends upon what sort of pressure flows from that speculation. The problems that led to the Samuels report emanated from ASIS, the agency directly under the control of the foreign minister, and were matters that had been brought to the attention of the foreign minister. It seems that they principally related to a failure of the administration of this minister in its labour relations, a failure to treat servants of the government in a civilised and sensible way.

Mr Holdich, who seems also, impliedly, to be getting some of the blame from this minister when he talks up the qualifications of Mr Holdich's successor, had brought down in his public reports that were tabled in this parliament the fact that at least one of those officers had not been treated according to the normal principles of natural justice. That had been brought to the attention of this minister, and no action had been taken by him to address the very serious allegations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep to the facts.

—I will. Go back and read the Hansard of 22 February 1994 and read your answers. You will see it all there, chapter and verse. You said that you saw the public reports, and I think you said that some counselling of ASIS staff would be adequate. You have a major indictment put down by the watchdog, the Inspector-General, and you did not act upon it.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the Inspector-General did say that the circumstances were so serious that a particular officer should be offered compensation. Then it seems that, with the support of the foreign minister, the officer was offered compensation—but with threat, unfortunately.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean threat?

—That it either be accepted or it would be withdrawn with no negotiation. If we go back to the Hansard of 22 February and read what the minister said, we will see that he was treating this almost as if it were a civil litigation between two parties in an equal bargaining position. That is part of what the minister has failed to understand about his responsibility to staff who do not have the public protection that other public servants and other members of the community have. That gives him, although everyone now likes to dismiss it, a special responsibility and a special onus in relation to those staff. The compensation was offered under threat, and for it to be offered under threat in circumstances where an officer does not have the usual recourse to the courts that other members of the public have was simply disgraceful. That process was condoned by the foreign minister and was a further demonstration of his failure in that regard.
—Pathetic.

—The minister says, `Pathetic'. That is always the minister's answer. Whenever there is a failure in his administration, it is somebody else's fault. Whenever he is criticised, the criticism has to be pathetic—even though it has led to the Samuels report, and not only embarrassed the Commonwealth in terms of public revelations but also harmed and hurt individual Australians. Forget all that, he regards it as pathetic. The Miles Cooper excuse: it is always the responsibility of somebody other than him.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, Senator Evans ought to remember that for years the Inspector-General has said to him, `My office is unable to completely and sufficiently deal with these matters because we are under-resourced. The matters have stacked up, they are complicated, they involve difficult personal assessments, and it is impossible for me to do the job according to the standard that I would wish on the basis of the funding that you have provided.' We raised that with the minister in estimates, and his answer was, `Senator Hill, you do not understand that all bureaucrats want more money.' He dismissed it again.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was not even my bureaucrat. He is at arms length. He was in another portfolio.

—You chose to give the answer. In other words, you dismissed his criticism that part of the problem is that your government had under-resourced his office. Despite it being under-resourced, he had nevertheless raised publicly and with Senator Evans that these particular individuals had not received natural justice and that unsatisfactory process evolved from that.

PARA.TAB: Fourthly and finally, it now seems that the Inspector-General of ASIS had said to the minister that serious public consequences were likely to flow unless the minister faced up to his responsibility and suggested the course of an inquiry. In February 1994, when we raised this issue with the minister—he did not volunteer it—his answer was, `I have been thinking about an inquiry for some time.' He now says that he was thinking about it since the previous year.

Senator Evans may have done a lot of thinking, but he failed to act. He came into the chamber the other day and said, `You are all speaking with the benefit of hindsight.' The trouble is that there was so much material on the public record, let alone what he had been told privately, that should have led him to reach the conclusion that such an inquiry was warranted. He did not do that until the matter had got out of hand and until there had been public damage as a result of his failure to properly act.

TALK.START.PARA: —What weight do you give to the confidentiality obligation that these characters have? Is this the blackmail theory of government?

—No, it is not. That is another way that you try to avoid your responsibility. I do not condone somebody who is under secret obligations making public material in breach of that obligation. I understand the pressure that these individuals are under when your processes cannot accord them natural justice and when they have a minister responsible for their administration who is totally uninterested, who does not care two hoots. I understand the stresses that flow from that.

PARA.TAB: Minister Evans quoted from the Samuels report today. With regard to how these people were treated, Mr Justice Samuels said `deplorable' in relation to the wife of one of these agents. `Highly inappropriate' was another expression that was used. He is talking about your administration. These matters have been brought to your attention. Your head of this agency had suggested a course of action that was open to you, and all you did was say that you were going to think about it. You thought about it for too long. You failed to act, and detrimental consequences to this nation flowed from your failure to act.

All I wanted to do today was put things back in perspective. The minister has been happy to come in here today and say that it is the fault of the media, it is the fault of the agents, and imply that it is the fault of the Inspector-General. What he failed to say is that principally it is his fault. He is the minister responsible for this agency, and he failed in his responsibility. It is about time that he accepted some of the blame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal briefly with the ministerial statement. I will make some introductory comments then get to the heart of the matter which, as Senator Hill pointed out, is the government's accountability and responsibility in this matter. Then I want to say something about the public Samuels report, then deal with the minister's tabling statement.

PARA.TAB: At the outset, I would like to compliment the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) on this report. It is a very well structured report and is very well put together. A fair bit of thought has been put into it. I do not agree with all of it and I will come to some of those points later. At the end of the day, we have to come to the conclusion, though, that this is a political report, designed to protect the government's back and to deflect criticism.

Having said that, it certainly makes some positive contributions to the debate on how the Australian intelligence community can be handled. That matter has been of great concern to me over a large number of years, particularly the facet that relates to parliamentary accountability of these agencies. I have certainly changed my thinking over the years I have been in this place from an initial view that the parliament, as part of the Westminster system—unlike the American system—could not become involved in the affairs of the agencies in an effective way. I now believe there is a limited role for the parliament in an oversight capacity.

I support the need for the intelligence community. I do not believe that the world is an ideal place and we can live in splendid isolation and cherish our ideals. It is important that we know what is going on in the nations of our region—what they are up to. Every other country does it although that is no justification for the requirement to exist in the first place. It is essential for the long-term national security of the country that we have an effective security service.

I really wonder whether there is a case today to have a secret intelligence service like ASIS, since every country collects intelligence and some countries do not have an official secrets act. If there is no official secrets act, there are no secrets to hide. I do not see why we cannot be quite open about a lot of the activities that ASIS performs. I would be prepared to consider a different title for the organisation—but that is a bit of a red herring at the moment.

The other point I want to make about ASIS is that, to the best of my knowledge, it does a good job operationally. It is certainly not perfect and a few quite comical blunders have emerged in public in the last decade. But I have no hesitation in supporting the quality of the product it is producing and its operations in the field.

But the heart of the problem we are dealing with is the internal administration of ASIS, what is frequently and colloquially referred to as man management. The way it handles its staff obviously is quite appalling and indefensible. A secondary matter in this issue is the culture within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the great and long-term antipathy it has to members of the intelligence community and members of the Defence Force. In one of the instances, the problem arose basically because of the antipathy of a member of the foreign affairs department. He was running stories about a member of ASIS.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you know that is old truth; this is not current truth in terms of the culture of the department.
—I have a deep and intimate knowledge of the culture within the department of foreign affairs.
—I don't think you do; you are out of date.

—Not at all. The criticism of the government does not relate to secrecy. The operational side of ASIS is not in dispute. What we are talking about is something which can and must be exposed to the light of public scrutiny. We are dealing with how the careers and lives of members of ASIS are handled by their administrators.

PARA.TAB: In essence, this matter arose because a small number of the staff of ASIS were genuinely badly treated. They felt they had no escape valve. As to whether they were justified in going public, I simply do not have enough information to make that judgment. But on the information I have, and as I see it, I would agree with the minister that there was no justification for them to go public on any operational matter whatsoever—and I deplore that.

But that leaves us with the matter of dealing with the clear failures within the ASIS administration. The responsibility for that rests with the Minister for Foreign Affairs. When the administration within ASIS was so bad that they had no other outlet, when they had been failed by the Inspector-General in the discharge of his duty to deal with their grievances and when the minister was made aware of it, the minister had an absolutely unavoidable obligation to do something. Yet the minister did nothing. He received a letter from the Director-General. Earlier this week, when I asked him how many letters of such a nature he had ever received from the Director-General of ASIS, he admitted, `Well, this was the only one.'

It was an extraordinary circumstance that the Director-General should write to his minister. In essence, what he said to the minister was, `We have a major problem here and the only way we can defuse it is by holding an inquiry that is divorced from the department, so it is seen to be objective. If we do that, we may be able to close the situation down and do no damage. If it is not done, then there are great risks to national security.' The minister cavalierly dismissed that letter. He dissembled later and said, `Well, I was thinking about it all along.' Obviously, at the time, the minister thought he would hide behind the traditional shield and buttress of ministers in relation to security matters and take the view that he would not comment—neither confirm nor deny—but that did not work in this case.

So we have the tragedy that we have at the present time. We have careers and lives ruined. We have national security put at risk. You cannot quantify the damage that has been done to Australia's national interests because we have offended everyone in the international community. We have offended our friends. We have offended our enemies. We have offended those who are neutral to our position. We have been caught out in the most appalling way by the consequences of the minister not dealing responsibly with this situation. Believe me, we have not seen the end of it.

As the Samuels report points out, some of these events go back 10 years. The way the whole thing has been handled will lead to a lot more agents, regrettably, coming out and running stories. Whether they are true or false, it will not matter, but they will be very damaging to Australia's reputation. As Senator Hill said, we have agreements with other powers in relation to the exchange of intelligence information. There has always been great suspicion in the United States and the United Kingdom about the security forces in Australia under a Labor government. They have had their worst fears amplified and reinforced by the events of the last few weeks.

All the nations in the region are offended. They are people of great tact and sensibility. They are all offended by the bugging of the Chinese embassy and things like that. To turn around and say, as Senator Evans is trying to say, that other departments in other countries have faults is irrelevant. Senator, two wrongs do not make a right, and I am sorry you do not know that.

It was the irresponsibility of this minister, the dereliction of the responsibilities vested in him, that led to the avoidable mess that we are in today. It has seen careers destroyed, lives put under great stress, cost the Commonwealth I do not know how many tens of millions of dollars, and put the whole of our international relations at risk as a consequence of it.

I would like to turn briefly to the Samuels report and make a few points. The very first page of the Samuels report—I am talking about the report that was released a month or so ago to the public—says:

SPEECH.PARA: The collection of such secret material depends on people who often put their lives and liberties at considerable risk.

That is one of the first points. The government has a responsibility to these people because they are different from the public servants sitting in the safety of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade buildings whose lives are not put at risk.

PARA.TAB: The other point I make about the Samuels report is that it sets out to damn those who made the complaints—the complainants, as the minister calls them. At every opportunity within this public document the people who complain are damned and given no tolerance or understanding in any way. There is absolutely no blame attributed to the press. Anyone in this building knows very well that when you talk to the press, what you say may or may not be presented accurately. I simply do not know, because I do not know what these officers said to the press. I do know what appeared in the press. Some of those things were pretty colourful. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Although information published in the Four Corners program on operational matters was skewed towards the false, evidence presented to us of action and reaction in other countries satisfies us that the publication was damaging.

The implication of that statement, apart from the international consequences of it, is that the information from complainants that appeared in public was false. There is a comment on the next page, `by publishing what they were told'. The implication there was that the press was accurate. I am not sure about that. Towards the end of the minister's statement he comments about something that does not appear in the public Samuels report. On page 12 of the typescript of his report he states:
The Commissioners found that, in some instances, journalists had published allegations about ASIS which they had good reason to suspect were untrue.

It may be that in the original Samuels report there was a more objective view taken of the quality of the reports that appeared in public. Maybe what we are dealing with in this public report of Samuels is a political document that was written in the minister's office that tried to put a favourable spin on it for the government. I do not know that; we just do not have that information.

PARA.TAB: I would like to deal briefly with the two complaints. The first case deals at length with a psychological report. The report apparently was compiled by an unregistered psychologist. The first thing that happened was that it was not done with informed consent. In other words, the subject was not told he was the subject of a psychological report.

The second thing about it seems to be that it was done on the run. It was not done as part of a formal clinical assessment. It was done at a casual social meeting, an interview or a series of interviews in the office. That is a gross breach of medical ethics. You cannot do those things. Psychiatrists and psychologists do not analyse people on superficial contact. There is a formal clinical assessment process. If this person had been a registered psychologist, he certainly would have been deregistered, struck off the register for an act like that. It was an appalling breach of medical ethics. Samuels finds that on page 7 of his report. On several occasions he states:

SPEECH.PARA: We consider that this use of the report, however it occurred and whatever the intended purpose, was highly inappropriate.

That is a gross understatement. This report was used against one of the officers—an illegally gathered and probably quite inaccurate psychological assessment. That is the stuff that the Soviet secret police used against the enemies of the state. It is an absolutely unconscionable action. This happened in Australia. It happened in a department and in an organisation responsible to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It is the sort of tactics that got the Soviet psychological association expelled from the world body. It is absolutely unheard of that techniques like that should be used in Australia.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the day, the Samuels inquiry found that, while the first complainant had been very badly treated, he had no justification to go public with his complaints.

In relation to the second case, the original complaints against this officer were initiated by an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The complaints were directed against him and his wife. His wife was not an employee of the Commonwealth; she was a wife. She was not in any way responsible or answerable to the Commonwealth.

That report, as the Samuels inquiry found, was based upon little more than `unauthenticated gossip'. In other words, a senior officer of ASIS and his wife were subjected to an attack on the basis of what Samuels described as unauthenticated gossip. When the officer who made those charges was asked at the Samuels inquiry to sign a statement, he refused to do so. The person who made that unauthenticated gossip refused to sign the document at the inquiry when the evidence was presented to him of what he had said about this officer and his wife.

All the rules of evidence and all the processes of the Australian law were denied to that officer. He had no human rights bill, no civil or political rights and no privacy act to protect him. Some of those legal recourses are denied to him because of the fact that he was an officer of ASIS. They were not denied to his wife, legally; but in reality they were.

Also in the Samuels inquiry is the implication that the officers had received generous compensation. My advice is that they were offered something like $10,000 or $12,000 compensation plus a year's salary. What we are dealing with here are officers who are highly specialised, who put their lives at risk from time to time in the interest of the nation, who serve overseas and who do tasks for which there are no civilian counterparts.

There are no advertisements—however hard we look on a Saturday morning in the positions vacant of the Australian—for retired or resigned ASIS officers. They cannot go up to an employer after 15, 20 or 25 years service, ask for a job and present a CV of their activities. They are specialists and the country has an obligation to them. To suggest that $10,000 or $12,000 is compensation for someone who has been driven out of the service as a consequence of unauthenticated gossip or of a bodgie psychological report is absolutely absurd and indefensible, yet this is what happened.

The safety valve that should have existed for these officers with their grievance was the Inspector-General. For a variety of reasons, the Inspector-General was the light that failed. It was not only his own fault, but his own lack of abilities obviously contributed to an inability to solve the difficulties. As a consequence, the Director-General wrote to the minister, and we all know that the minister did nothing about it.

I must say that the minister goes on to praise the new appointee. I know the new Inspector-General. I have known him for 15 or 16 years in the parliament. While I have the greatest of respect for him, his knowledge of operations in the intelligence field would be quite negligible and the ability to bring mature judgment on difficult issues like this would also be non-existent.

I want to go on to the minister's response itself. I do not wish to re-cover what I have talked about in relation to the complainants. I do wish to deal with the matter of a parliamentary committee. I said at the outset that parliamentary oversight is something we have to turn our minds to. I agree with the recommendation that it should be a small committee. This paper suggests that the committee should have six members. I would be quite happy with four—two from the government and two from the opposition, with the chairman being a government nominee with a casting and a deliberative vote. I certainly believe the committee should not be larger than six. It should include senior parliamentarians who have some knowledge and interest in the field and who can bring some judgment to bear on these matters.

One of the critical points, though, is that the members of the committee should be selected by the Leader of the Government, the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. I do not believe it should be a matter for ballot within the party room. It is not a popularity contest, and the people who hold a committee appointment must be people of some experience who are able to bring some abilities to the task.

I am very conscious of the shortcomings of the ASIO joint committee. I was the second Liberal member to serve on that committee, and that committee is a sham. It is a sham put up by the Labor Party as a sop to its left wing. When I was on that committee, the chairman of the committee was compromised, in the intelligence sense, to the Soviets. I know the Prime Minister of the day knew that, and I know at least one of his senior cabinet ministers in the House of Representatives knew that, and I suspect a large number did. For a government to put in as chairman of that committee a person who was compromised is absolutely inexcusable. The rest of the nominees of the Labor Party on that committee ranged from the loony left through the academic left to the harmless left. There was no other group from the Labor Party on the committee at that time, and the committee was a sham.

The other suggestion I would make about an intelligence committee for the parliament is that it should have a finite term. The members probably should be appointed for three or four years, and they should be out of phase, 50 per cent retiring at a time, so that there is some continuity. It is very important that people do not serve for a lifetime on the intelligence committee, because they become captive of the organisations. A finite period of three to four years—the way the Americans do it—is absolutely essential.

The minister discussed the organisation and management of ASIS. Since time is short, I do not propose to go into that in great detail, but the statement he made—that the situation we have at present `led to the development of a culture which values conformity above diversity and executive direction over consultation'—is perfectly true.

There is a need to inject within the management of ASIS itself some external points of view, and that is quite different to a parliamentary committee. Maybe it is possible to bring people in from outside—and I do think there are Australians in industry at senior management levels who would be prepared to serve and who could profitably serve in an advisory management committee and bring a different perspective to what is necessarily an always inward-looking culture.

I do not wish to take any more time discussing the protection of intelligence sources and methods, which takes some pages here, or go on for too long about the resolutions of grievances and complaints. That really does need to be addressed, and probably the propositions made by the department can be made to work.

In summary, I do support the need for the intelligence community. It works under enormous difficulties and it always must operate under difficulties because of the very nature of its work. On the evidence I have, and from what I have seen over the years, I think ASIS does a good job in the field. It clearly has problems, though, with its internal management, and the government must accept the responsibility for that. What we have seen from the minister at the present time is a total rejection of that responsibility. That is something that the parliament cannot tolerate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues in their criticism of the government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) in the handling of this matter relating to the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. I share the comments of my colleague Senator MacGibbon with regard to welcoming the government's response. It is a very important report. I particularly welcome the government's intention to move ASIS from an executive to a legislative charter—I am sure that is a very important move—and also to set up the parliamentary oversight committee. I also note in the minister's statement that ASIS exempt operating accounts will be opened up to external audit by the audit office, and I welcome that.

PARA.TAB: The heart of the matter and why we are talking about this matter today really comes from the grievances that were raised by several ex-ASIS officers and one wife which brought this whole matter to a head. As Senator MacGibbon said before me, it really showed incompetent management within ASIS, within its external review for complaints—that is, the Inspector-General's role—and basically incompetence by the minister in handling this whole matter. The report clearly shows that there have to be substantial changes, not only the external ones relating to legislative matters and parliamentary oversight, but also the internal management procedures. I will come to that later.

Undoubtedly, the grievances led to this substantial review of ASIS, which would not have happened without the people being forced to go public. It is sad that they were forced to do it, but I can understand their situation. Whether it is right or wrong that they went public, I have no way of telling.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you don't condone them for going public?

—No, I don't condone them for going public, but I can understand them being forced to do it. I think they were forced to do it by the foreign minister. What would the foreign minister have done if he had been in their situation? The five people followed through proper procedure within the organisation. They were frustrated by that procedure within the service. They then referred their concerns to the Inspector-General. He went laboriously through the process. In one case negotiations with him went on for 3 1/2 years, but in the end it broke down; it did not work.

PARA.TAB: The people concerned then approached the foreign minister. I understand that one or two of them approached him personally. Then they made a plea through Miles Cooper, the minister's senior adviser, for the minister to sit down and talk with them—either individually or as a group—but he refused. They then wrote to the minister about this matter, asking him to look at it again. One of them wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Again, they were frustrated; nothing happened. What else would you expect them to do, having gone through all this frustration?

These people had a genuine concern for Australia. They were not like agent Ames in the USA who went across to the other side because he believed he had been wrongly treated. These people did not do that; they loved Australia, they believed there was improper management within the organisation and they wanted the matter exposed and corrected. Unfortunately, through this minister they came to the conclusion that they had to expose it in the public arena in order to get it corrected. We are seeing here today that the commissioners did recommend that management had to be substantially changed. So their major complaints have been recognised. I hope that the government treats them fairly.

As Senator MacGibbon mentioned a few minutes ago, we also know that the Director-General of ASIS advised the minister to have an inquiry and that he refused to do so at the time. Their last resort was to go public. As a result of going public, first of all the minister denied that there would be any inquiry. I will quote from the Hansard of 22 February in which he answered a question from Senator Troeth with regard to why the government had not decided to establish a proper inquiry. With regard to the complainants he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is my own judgment that those cases have been fully and fairly resolved; I have seen the documentation associated with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in black and white.
—It is.
—The minister failed.
—He absolutely failed. He really failed in his duty. What has happened from there? We have the commissioners recommending a substantial change in the management of the organisation.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the key points about that in the minister's statement. He says that the commissioners propose a number of management reforms aimed at developing an internal culture which respects differences and diversities between staff and management as being healthy rather than threatening. They propose a greater emphasis on corporate planning, a greater delegation of functions, more uniform and transparent staff selection procedures, improved career opportunities, improved staff counselling, fairer and more transparent procedures for the internal investigation of allegations of misconduct and a clearer and more transparent policy by ASIS of expectations of the spouses of officers.

Is not that an indictment of the management of this organisation? It really is. For a public report to come out and for the minister to come out and say what has to be done about an organisation makes me understand in some way why these people who have been aggrieved for so many years took the step and, in effect, forced this inquiry. The good thing for all Australians is that we are seeing a positive response from the government in, first of all, going down the legislative route, admitting the parliamentary oversight, providing the Auditor-General with access to accounts which were previously closed off to him and, probably more importantly, making all those key points about the management of the organisation that I have just referred to from the minister's own statement.

I trust that the government will treat those people fairly and give them due compensation. They have been great contributors to the Australian public. Even though I said before that I am not sure whether they should have gone public—I do not condone that—the fact is that they did, they caused this inquiry and they have caused these changes. The minister should be condemned for his failure to act to fix up these matters before the whole thing was blown up in the public arena.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Report on the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. I would like to make a few comments because I find this report an incredible indictment on the efficiency, or lack of it, of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). The responsibility of the minister is quite clearly outlined on page 12 of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The responsibility assigned by the Directive to the Minister for Foreign Affairs makes the Minister the most important element in the control and accountability of ASIS. The Minister bears the political responsibility for what the Service does. The effectiveness of the control and accountability of ASIS depends crucially on the competence of both the Minister and the Director-General and the trust between them.

You could have bluffed me! Having listened to this statement by the minister today, I agree exactly with what Senator Hill said earlier on—that is, it is incredible, it is breathtaking to think that the minister has blamed everybody but himself. He has failed the test in the worst possible way by neglecting his staff; by neglecting their concerns, their complaints and their genuine questions on matters that have been raised by me and many other colleagues over an extended period of time. Had the minister half a wit about him or any concern for such an important service as ASIS, he would have taken on board the serious questions that were being raised at estimates and in the parliament. He chose not to do so.

PARA.TAB: To my mind, the former Director-General has also been negligent in his role as detailed in the report as he is personally responsible for the individual and collective performance of officers. Quite clearly the concerns and complaints raised by officers have been overlooked by many of these people. The report indicates too that complaints raised by personnel had some foundation. The use of an unofficially obtained psychological report on one of the complainants is just disgusting.

In his speech the minister said that briefings given to the opposition should remain strictly confidential in order to protect national security. Following my repeated questions to the minister at estimates, he kindly offered me a briefing. I had that briefing, and I have kept everything absolutely confidential—I might say, though, with great difficulty at times because some of the media reports clearly knew what I knew, and some of the journalists clearly knew what I had been told.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs is like the Attorney-General, Minister Lavarch: there is no acceptance or acknowledgment whatsoever of the decent role that the opposition plays in this exercise. Minister Lavarch has never acknowledged what Senator Vanstone did last year with the truckload of information that came from the Attorney-General's Department. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has never acknowledged the fact that we in the opposition have sought to keep these matters confidential, even in the light of the fact that he has made a huge botch-up of the whole thing.

The fact that virtually all the officers at the centre of the problem were either not informed about allegations or were not given any answers to concerns is a great worry to me. The fact that the officers were denied any opportunity to see a report such as the illegally and unofficially obtained psychological report is even more scandalous and an atrocious reflection on both the minister and the director-general.

As I have said, the minister should have realised that those questions over an extended period of time would lead to some trouble. The fact that the minister today, at the very beginning of his speech, said—

SPEECH.PARA: I had been considering in 1993, well before any individual grievances became public, whether it was time for another review of ASIS—
is also breathtaking.

PARA.TAB: This minister knew in 1993 that there were problems afoot but he chose to ignore them—he chose to deflect them willy-nilly to his officers. While we cannot condone officers and former officers raising their concerns publicly, the fact that they did indicates, in the clearest possible terms, that their concerns were falling on deaf ears.

The officers wrote to the minister with no response—no response! Is that not a neglect of duty? Of course, it is. Let us never forget where the buck stops—with this minister, Senator Evans. He failed every test set for him in the resolution of so many problems. The mere fact that there is a belief in the service that to raise a complaint is to put one's future at risk is a further indictment.

It never ceases to amaze me that there are examples after examples of the fact that the government's loud and long trumpeting about workplace conditions, equality, fairness and justice is simply ignored or overridden by ministers when it so suits. There was no fairness, no equality, no justice at all in the treatment of these officers.

In the case of ASIS, I am the first to admit that staff should, in the first instance, be able to obtain satisfaction from the Inspector-General. However, when that fails, surely there should be a level of responsibility accepted and exercised by the minister. I repeat: this minister chose not to do it and he should stand condemned for not doing it. It is preposterous for the minister to suggest he had no idea of the situation before that time in 1994. In his response today, the minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has agreed with the Commissioners' recommendation that the complainants and their legal representatives be allowed to see those parts of the second volume which relate to their individual cases, on conditions of strict confidentiality.

So they should be. But it is all too late. He shut the door in those officers' faces time and time again. Now, to make a big fellow of himself, he is saying, `Oh, you can have a look at the report.' They should be allowed to see it. They should have known what was going on. They should have been privy to the information about themselves long ago. This minister should have seen to it but he chose not to. He also said:
ASIS is an arm of the executive government, and is subject to Ministerial direction like any other department or agency of government.

Those are the minister's own words. Well, you could have fooled me! He has walked away from everything that is wrong, everything that is bad, everything that has affected the officers, and he is consistently blaming other people.

PARA.TAB: The other significant factor is that the minister admitted today that the commissioners did find that there had been some shortcomings in ASIS's internal management, particularly with regard to the methods it adopted to deal with allegations of misconduct. Since the minister knew of those allegations, why did he not direct that there be a smart resolution so that the whole situation would not go public? We would not have the Four Corners program, we would not have had Senator McMullan talking out about it, we would not have the minister himself coming into the chamber and flapping his gums on it, in a most inappropriate way, if he had taken proper action at an early stage. Today he also said:

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment of appropriate grievance mechanism, as outlined . . . should make such a defence—
a defence of public interest, I might add—

unnecessary in cases where matters of personnel administration are involved. And, as the Commissioners themselves make clear, any officer with concerns about possible improper activity or serious maladministration has an avenue already through the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security for expressing those concerns: certainly there should be no need ever to unlawfully disclose information.
That is true. That method of expressing concern should be available—that is, if it works.

PARA.TAB: It did not work in this case. The minister saw to it that it did not work. I deliberately say that because the minister knew that there were problems. If he wanted to ensure that it worked, he could have. He went on to say in relation to the resolution of grievances and complaints relating to ASIS:

SPEECH.PARA: The existence of differences between staff and management in ASIS is not inherently a cause for greater concern than it would be in another organisation.

It is. By the sheer nature of ASIS, it is of great concern because if people act in desperation—and I say desperation because that is the way in which these officers acted—they are going to make these things public. They are going to have to make these things public. So there is a difference.

PARA.TAB: The minister should recognise the difference between ASIS and other instrumentalities. The minister also admits that the commissioners `noted the need for ASIS management to take particular measures to meet its duty effectively'. Is that an admission, or not, of the fact that there were shortcomings? The minister also said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioners also recommended clarification of the roles and responsibilities of the ASIS staff ombudsman and the ASIS psychologist.
So say all of us after what happened with this exercise. The minister continued:
The Commissioners found that the preparation of a secret psychological report on one of the complainants without his knowledge, and the subsequent use of that report, to have been highly improper.

Is that not interesting? There is no indication whatsoever in this statement that the minister has accepted that that psychological report should not have been done and that he, in the end, takes responsibility for the fact that it was and that the information was never conveyed to the person. The person was never notified that any report was conducted on him at the time. The minister does not accept one shred of responsibility. He went on to say:
But in many cases the conclusions and recommendations of the Inspector-General were rejected by the complainants, who then chose to pursue their cased through the media.

Yes, that is right. Having spoken to a number of these complainants over a long period of time, I am not surprised. The amount of contact that they have had with ASIS management and with the minister—all to no avail—was appalling.

PARA.TAB: I do not condone going public, particularly when one is subjected to the conditions applying to ASIS officers. But surely that is all the more reason why the minister must take responsible action. The minister continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioners have made several observations on the handling of these complaints by the former Inspector-General and they have found deficiencies in the procedural approach taken to the investigations and the time to resolve the cases.

The minister has noted that that has been a problem. I ask the question again: did he do anything about it? The simple answer is no. He chose not to do anything about it. I think the minister should be absolutely and utterly condemned in this place for his inactivity and his inattention to his job as minister. The buck does stop with him. A number of ASIS officers and a wife have been seriously aggrieved by this process and lack of concern by the minister for which this report clearly identifies he has the responsibility. At some stage this minister must accept responsibility and not wash his hands of everything coming under his control when it goes wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to give a reply to a question that Senator Patterson asked me today.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article by Ian Hamilton in the Herald Sun concerns the removal of the savings provision for saved managed investments; that is, market-linked managed investments bought before 8 September 1988, and friendly society bonds bought before 1 January 1988.

PARA.TAB: To help bring in the extended deeming provisions, the government will be giving a massive concession to people with these investments. This is not to encourage or force pensioners to change their investments but to remove barriers to them doing so. It will allow pensioners to change investments before extended deeming starts, if they wish, without their pension being badly affected by the old on-realisation rules for saved managed investments.

Currently, if these managed investments are cashed in, a person's pension may be considerably reduced because past capital growth is assessed in one 12-month period following withdrawal. Persons may lose their entire pension for a year under this rule. To help bring in the new rules, the government is going to drop this rule from the time the necessary legislation is passed. This is a generous concession which means that past growth accumulated on these investments will never be counted under the income test. It is not just a window of opportunity before extended deeming starts; the rule will be dropped forever.

Pensioners are being advised of the arrangements which will be put in place for these investments in the June edition of the Age Pension News. It will make clear that if people reinvest money from a saved managed investment before extended deeming starts, their new investment will be subject to the current income test rules until July 1996. Age Pension News will also make clear that people should not rush into decisions about changing investments and that they may wish to use the DSS financial information service, or their own financial advisers, to get information and advice.

The arrangements for saved managed investments are an essential part of the move to a fairer and simpler system of means testing. The complexities caused by the savings provisions were a major barrier to simplifying the means test. Removing these savings provisions allows the range of complex rules for the assessment of financial investments to be replaced with one simple and fair set of income test rules.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the minister for her answer. She said that some of the information would be available in Age Pension News. I have some concerns about that because I am not sure when the next issue of Age Pension News will be available.
—June.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the seventh report of 1995, Construction of a multi-level carpark for the Federal Airports Corporation at Melbourne Airport, and the eighth report of 1995, Housing development at HMAS Coonawarra, Northern Territory. SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's Seventh report of 1995 relates to the proposed construction of a multi-level carpark for the Federal Airports Corporation at Melbourne Airport.

Melbourne Airport is the second busiest in Australia and is subject to continuing growth in passenger movements. The existing short-term carpark is suffering severe congestion and frequent closure. The Federal Airports Corporation submitted to the Committee that it is necessary to increase the capacity of the short-term carpark by providing a multi-level carpark adjacent to the terminal.
The scope of the proposal examined by the Committee includes a four-level, open-sided concrete carpark.

It also includes—associated facilities such as office accommodation for car rental companies and police, accommodation for some high vehicles, lifts, stairs, pedestrian bridges, goods loading dock, landscaping and planting.
The preliminary cost estimate of the project is $55 million.
The Committee has recommended that the proposal should proceed.
The Committee found that current short-term carparking facilities and arrangements at Melbourne Airport are inadequate.
There is a need to upgrade short-term carparking to overcome current shortages and provide for future growth.

In response to a suggestion from the Public Transport Users Association that improved public transport from the airport to the city may obviate the need for a new building, the Committee found that the majority of motor vehicles requiring short-term parking emanate from the wider metropolitan area and other parts of the State.
The Committee notes nevertheless that options for a longer term future rail link to the Central Business District have been identified and easements are being protected.

Because the new carpark will be some distance from the terminal building and will be linked by three walkways, the Committee has recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation should consider the provision of mechanical moving walkways.

A substantial building site between the terminal and the carpark has been reserved for a future hotel. The Committee has some misgivings about the suitability and practicality of locating a hotel between the terminal and the carpark. Accordingly the Committee has recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation should re-examine the arrangement of carpark and future hotel sites to satisfy itself that the proposed sites are the best locations for both.

Two features of the carpark include a loading dock and tunnel which it is planned will facilitate the movement of goods to and from the terminal. Qantas raised a number of concerns about the tunnel and the loading dock and the Committee has recommended that during the development of detailed designs the Federal Airports Corporation should continue discussions with Qantas and other terminal users about the functionality of the loading dock and tunnel.

In the same vein, in response to a submission from the Melbourne Metropolitan Fire Brigades Board, the Committee has recommended that the FAC should, during design development, consult the brigade about modifications to State regulatory fire safety requirements before they are submitted to the Building Appeals Board for approval.
The Committee's Eighth Report of 1995 deals with a proposed housing development at HMAS Coonawarra, Northern Territory.

The proposal examined by the Committee involves the construction of 32 family dwellings by the Defence Housing Authority on HMAS Coonawarra. The site for the proposed housing is adjacent to existing family units which have been completed over the past two years. Upon completion the new houses will be allocated to families of Army non-commissioned and commissioned officers. Included in the project are supporting community facilities.
The estimated cost of the proposed work is $6.8 million.
The Committee has recommended that the work should proceed.

The Committee concluded that as a consequence of the Army Presence in the North project there will be a need for a continuing program of housing acquisitions or Defence Housing Authority-sponsored new construction to be provided in Darwin to cater for planned relocation of Defence personnel.

The Committee found that in order to reduce reliance on Temporary Rental Allowances and to avoid over-reliance on acquisitions, there is merit in the Defence Housing Authority proceeding with the funding and development of new construction.

The Northern Territory Government pointed out to the Committee that the site proposed for the housing development is prone to noise from a number of sources, including aircraft, speedway racing and road traffic.

The Committee is not convinced that a housing subdivision situated in close proximity to two major roads and within a short distance from a speedway and underneath an aircraft flight path, will not have substantial noise problems either now or in the near future.

The Committee raised these concerns with the Defence Housing Authority and has approved the proposal only on the assurance by DHA that whilst recognising the potential disadvantages, they are outweighed by the advantages. The Committee remains to be convinced of this.
The Committee also raised concerns about the close proximity of the houses.

The Committee raised the question of the payment of subcontractors with the Defence Housing Authority. The Defence Housing Authority is considering making it mandatory for builders to certify that these payments have been made. The Committee believes this is an urgent matter and has recommended that the Defence Housing Authority should move swiftly to make it a mandatory requirement.
I commend the reports to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: SMALL SUPERANNUATION ACCOUNTS BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: A decade ago, most workers had no access to superannuation and Australia lacked a strategy to address the major challenges posed by an ageing population.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, the Government's superannuation strategy means that around 90 per cent of all employees have superannuation. Many of them have superannuation for the first time as a result of the Superannuation Guarantee.
This bill together with the Superannuation Laws Amendment (Small Accounts and Other Measures) Bill 1995 gives effect to the Statement on Superannuation Policy made by the Treasurer on 28 June 1994.

The Treasurer's statement confirms the Government's vision for superannuation. It strengthens the existing superannuation system to ensure that it works more equitably for everyone—particularly people with small superannuation accounts.

Small superannuation accounts are inevitable. After all most new employees begin with a small entitlement to contributions. This is particularly the case for casual, itinerant and part time workers such as hospitality staff and fruit pickers.

The problem with small accounts is that the fees and charges imposed on them can be more than the investment income earned. Clearly this contributes nothing to retirement savings and is not acceptable.
The Government is implementing a range of measures to deal with this problem:
.`member protection' of small superannuation accounts;
.measures to reduce the number of multiple accounts;
.the Superannuation Holding Accounts Reserve established by this bill; and
.other initiatives including measures contained in the Superannuation Laws Amendment (Small Accounts and Other Measures) Bill 1995.

Taken together, these measures will ensure that compulsory superannuation contributions add greatly to national savings in the years to come and will help ensure higher retirement incomes for all Australians.
Member Protection

Superannuation funds will be asked to `member protect' accounts by taking steps to prevent fees and charges from totalling more than investment income. Member protection will apply to any superannuation account under $1,000 which contains Superannuation Guarantee or award superannuation contributions.

The Government has been promoting member protection as its preferred approach to dealing with the small balances problem. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission and Australian Taxation Office has written to all funds, financial advisers, trustees and employers, to explain the new rules.

Details of the member protection rules were contained in Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations gazetted on 5 April 1995. These measures supplement existing regulations relating to the vesting of member benefits.
Reducing multiple superannuation accounts

In the area of reducing multiple superannuation accounts, the Government encourages people to transfer all their superannuation into one account. This will result in larger balances which are less likely to be lost or eroded by fees. It will also mean that funds have fewer small balances to member protect.

Last year, we asked the superannuation industry to establish a low cost `transfer protocol' for transferring benefits between funds. This should make it easier for people to transfer all of their superannuation to the fund used by their current employer.
The `transfer protocol' will reduce costs throughout the industry, particularly for the major industry fund administrators which cater to over 3.5 million industry fund members.

The Government intends to facilitate a `transfer protocol' by reducing the reporting requirements when benefits are transferred between funds. A high priority will be given to completing the necessary amendments to the Income Tax Regulations.

The Government would prefer to see funds and administrators voluntarily co-operating to ensure that the `transfer protocol' spreads throughout the industry. I understand the major fund administrators are working on a `transfer protocol' which they plan to make available to the industry more broadly. This is a welcome development which I will be monitoring closely. However, the Government will consider the feasibility of making the `transfer protocol' mandatory if this proves necessary in the future.
Tax Office Collection Mechanism

This bill establishes an alternative collection mechanism known as the Superannuation Holding Accounts Reserve (SHAR) administered by the Australian Taxation Office. SHAR should reduce the number of small superannuation accounts, and the overall costs of administering small accounts.
The Government is encouraging employers to use SHAR as a last resort only where they are unable to contribute to a fund which provides member protection for small balances.

Employers will be able to pay both compulsory and voluntary superannuation contributions into SHAR. There is no limit on the amount that can be paid in. However, income tax deductions for employer contributions will be limited to $1,200 per employee per annum. In addition, employers should not use SHAR where they have award or other obligations to contribute to a particular fund.

Each individual will have their own account which will amalgamate all the amounts paid by different employers. The ATO will write to people when an account has been opened for them explaining how SHAR will work. This information forms part of the Government's ongoing commitment to public education about the benefits of superannuation.
The ATO will write to people when their balance has reached $1,200 suggesting that they transfer their account to a superannuation fund.

Money paid into SHAR may be held in investments authorised under the Audit Act 1901 until the enactment of the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1995. Returns on those investments will be applied firstly to meeting the operating costs of the SHAR. Any remaining surplus will be applied as interest to account balances up to $1,200.

SHAR is designed to operate as a conduit between employers and the superannuation industry, and will not be a superannuation fund for the purposes of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993.
Financial implications

The estimated cost of establishing the Reserve is $5.6 million, and annual running costs are estimated at between $7.0 and $7.5 million. These annual running costs are expected to be offset by earnings on the funds held in the Reserve which is anticipated to be administered on a full cost recovery basis.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, the Government has announced that the public share offer for the Commonwealth's remaining 75 per cent equity in Qantas Airways Ltd will take place in the middle of 1995.

The Qantas Sale Act 1992, which established the legislative and administrative framework for the sale, received royal assent on 21 December 1992. Consistent with the conditions then prevailing in the aviation industry, the Qantas Sale Act imposed a limit of 35 per cent on the level of foreign ownership of Qantas. This was supported by a limitation on individual foreign holdings of 25 per cent, and a range of national interest provisions ensuring that Qantas' Australian status would be maintained.

The statutory national interest provisions require that Qantas be incorporated in Australia, its main operations base and headquarters remain in Australia, and the name of "Qantas" be preserved for the company's scheduled international passenger service. In addition, it is a requirement that the Chairman of Qantas and at least two-thirds of the Board be Australian citizens.

Following the 1993 amendments, the Air Navigation Act 1920 includes the same national interest provisions as the Qantas Sale Act, and requires that foreign airlines can hold no more than 25 per cent individually and 35 per cent in total of an Australian international airline other than Qantas. However, the Air Navigation Act imposes no overall limitation on holdings by foreigners other than foreign airlines, although if foreign holdings moved above 49 per cent, international carrier status may be challenged by Australia's bilateral aviation partners on the grounds that the carrier may no longer be seen as substantially Australian owned and controlled.
The Government believes it is desirable that Qantas should be subject to a similar foreign ownership regime as applies to Ansett and other potential Australian international airlines.

Therefore, the Government proposes in this bill to increase the overall foreign ownership limit for Qantas from 35 to 49 per cent and to restrict foreign airlines to holding no more than 25 per cent individually and 35 per cent in total of Qantas. The national interest provisions of the Qantas Sale Act would remain unchanged, as would the existing 25 per cent limit on individual holdings of foreigners.

The Government considers that all of its Australian ownership and control objectives for Qantas, as well as obligations under Australia's bilateral aviation treaties, would still be met under a higher foreign ownership limit. Placing Qantas in a similar position as applies to Ansett (and any other emerging Australian international airlines) will have no effect on Qantas' Australian status. That status is protected statutorily by the national interest provisions and the overall foreign ownership limit.

A consequence of the proposed change in foreign ownership limitations on Qantas is that the sizeable Qantas float would be able to access additional demand from international equity markets. British Airways already owns 25 of the 35 per cent of Qantas' shares available to foreign investors, and consequently without any change in the overall limit, a maximum of only 10 per cent could be sold to other foreigners. Indications were that under these arrangements there would be substantial unsatisfied offshore demand.

The participation of foreign investors should therefore assist in attracting full value for the Qantas offer, as the bids of those who routinely value and trade in international airline stocks could be accommodated. This could further the Government's objective of seeking, on behalf of taxpayers, the most successful outcome for the float. The ability of foreigners to participate more fully could also assist in establishing a healthy after market for Qantas' stock.

The interests of taxpayers should be better served if any additional offshore demand is able to be taken into account in establishing a fair and justifiable price for the sale of Qantas. In saying this it has to be recognised that even if substantial foreign demand for Qantas' shares emerges, Australian investors will be allocated more than two thirds of the Government's remaining 75 per cent shareholding.
Mr President, I commend the bill to the Senate.
