The bill makes amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993, the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953, the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992, and the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also makes minor technical amendments to a number of Acts as set out in Schedule 2 of the Bill.

An important element of the Government's child care policy is the Commonwealth Childcare Cash Rebate. Introduced in July 1994, this cash payment helps offset child care expenses for children while both parents are, or the sole parent is, working, studying, training or looking for work.

Parents who are using child care for any of these work-related purposes can claim a rebate on the cost of formal child care services, such as centre-based long day care and family day care, or informal child care, such as care provided by nannies and babysitters. The Childcare Cash Rebate is administered by the Health Insurance Commission (Medicare).

The introduction of the Childcare Cash Rebate recognises the fact that the cost of the child care is a legitimate work expense for parents in the labour force. It has improved the affordability of child care for many working parents.
This Bill includes amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 to ensure consistency with the intentions of the scheme.
The first group of amendments provide hardship provisions to assist certain groups of persons who are currently precluded from receiving the rebate but who should be entitled to the rebate.
These groups are:

PARA.TAB: children over the age of thirteen years who have a disability or other specified special need which requires ongoing child care;
parents who should be considered to have work-related commitments, such as those who are eligible for, but not in receipt of, a Carer Pension; and
families in which one parent has a work-related commitment but the other parent is unable to work or look after their children due to extenuating circumstances such as a medical condition.

SPEECH.PARA: An amendment is sought to allow carers under the age of eighteen years who have specified formal child care qualifications to register under the scheme.

Further amendments are proposed to confirm in legislation that family registration is able to be backdated to the date at which the family was first eligible to register, and that the rebate can be paid when a child is absent from child care for specified reasons.

Finally, there are some administrative amendments proposed to rectify a number of drafting anomalies which have arisen and to make consequential amendments to the Act to bring it in line with changes to other Commonwealth legislation.

These include amendments to allow the suspension of family and carer registrations if cancellation of registration is being considered. This will avoid unnecessary recoveries by Government while ensuring that individuals maintain their right to appeal against long-term decisions.
Other administrative amendments are proposed to:

PARA.TAB: allow the Health Insurance Commission to backdate carer registrations to the date at which they were first eligible to register;
cancel family or carer registrations and recover payments when an administrative error has been made;
ensure that the rebate is not paid for child care expenses which have been, or will be, reimbursed by another agent such as an employer;
clarify the eligibility of persons who are not Australian citizens by correcting the description of visa categories to bring the Act into line with changes in the Migration Act;
broaden the nature of courses which overseas students can be undertaking in order to be eligible for the rebate;
allow the Managing Director of the Health Insurance Commission to delegate powers;
allow the Minister to have some discretion over receipting requirements; and
to remove technical defects in the original Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the proposed amendments will be retrospective back to the introduction of the rebate on 1 July 1994, so as to provide maximum assistance to families who should have been entitled to the rebate.

Whilst the financial impact of these amendments will be minimal, they serve to strengthen the original intention of the Act and to clarify and facilitate certain procedural aspects of the Childcare Cash Rebate scheme.

The amendments proposed to the Health Insurance Act 1973 are designed to correct a number of minor drafting errors in the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Act 1994 which established the Professional Services Review Scheme. In addition, the amendments will allow the appointment as a President of a Professional Services Review Tribunal, a person who holds or has held judicial office in a State or Territory jurisdiction.

Professional Services Review Tribunals consider requests from affected practitioners for a review of a Determination of a penalty (which may include the disqualification from Medicare) following a finding by a Professional Services Review Committee that the practitioner has engaged in inappropriate practice.

It was not realised at the time the legislation was drafted that section 21 of the Acts Interpretation Act specifies that a reference in any Act to the word "office" shall be construed as a reference to an office in or for the Commonwealth. The proposed amendment corrects this oversight which has limited significantly the number of persons who can be considered for appointment as a Tribunal President.

The proposed amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 are designed to correct a deficiency in the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Act 1994. That Act, which gave the Health Insurance Commission the power to investigate fraud under Medicare and to deal directly with the Director of Public Prosecutions, does not allow the Health Insurance Commission to retain evidential material seized under the authority of a search warrant for more than 60 days unless proceedings for an offence to which that material may afford evidence is instituted within that period.

Although the powers of investigation legislation is modelled in large part on the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994, the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions has pointed out that the provision relating to the retention of seized material was based on a similar provision in an early version of the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Bill 1994. That latter provision was subsequently altered to allow the retention of evidential material until the reason for its seizure no longer exists or it is decided that it is not to be used in evidence. The proposed amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act provides for the retention of such material in similar circumstances.
The Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions has advised that, without the proposed amendments, the Commission's search warrant powers are effectively unusable.

The Bill also empowers the Health Insurance Commission to engage in hedging of investment transactions, provide consulting, management and related services and exercise its powers and perform its functions overseas. The Commission has undertaken a number of consultancies primarily, but not exclusively, under the auspices of the World Bank. As these activities are expanding, and moving beyond the use of spare capacity in the Commission's operations, it is desirable to make explicit provision to cover this activity. The Health Insurance Commission is an Australian organisation at the fore front of international best practice in the performance of its various functions. Its expertise is recognised both within Australia and internationally. The Commission is in a position to perform a flagship role for Australia in areas attracting growing international attention.

So far as the proposed hedging power is concerned, this is consistent with other Commonwealth legislation and has been addressed, on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, to resolve any doubt about the Commission's ability to enter into hedging transactions. Hedging is, of course, one of the tools necessary in a prudent and balanced investment program which includes some overseas investments. The Commission operates Medibank Private in competition with other private insurers and must have available to it the same opportunities to manage the funds vested in it by its members.

This Bill also contains amendments to parts of the National Health Act 1953 which regulate the administration of nursing homes. The Government has decided that these amendments should not await the introduction of the new Aged Care Act. The amendments to the current legislation are essential to address two immediate concerns that have been identified.

The first concern relates to the complexities of the current payment system. The second concern relates to nursing homes which are able to charge increased fees to their residents and yet fail to provide the basic standard of nursing and personal care.

The first concern is addressed by a series of minor amendments that relate to the simplification of the Nursing Home Payment System. Many of the criticisms of the administration of this Program relate to the complexity of the current system. Both the November 1994 Report of the Senate Community Affairs Committee Reference Committee on the "Validation of CAM and SAM Funding of Nursing Homes" and the Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 19 1994-95 "Efficiency Audit—Validation of Nursing Home Funding", acknowledge the complexities of the current system and have identified problems which have arisen as a direct result of these complexities. For example, the Auditor-General has identified problems in the delivery of appropriate information to nursing home proprietors relating to the Commonwealth's requirements for the payment of benefits.

As these simplification measures can be legally achieved by changes to subordinate legislation (that is the Nursing Homes Financial Arrangements Principles—a disallowable instrument), it is proposed to proceed down this path. This would allow simplification to proceed quickly and therefore result in a clear and demonstrable response to one of the concerns of the Auditor-General.

The introduction of these simplification measures will not result in any change in the entitlement of nursing home proprietors to Commonwealth benefits. These measures will not result in any change to the level of advances paid to nursing home proprietors.

The simplification measures will make it easier for a nursing home proprietor to see how the level of Commonwealth benefit was calculated. The current daily calculation of "loadings" [under or over expenditure of amounts paid for nursing and personal care] and "OCRE" [Other Cost Reimbursed Expenditure] will cease and these amounts will be included in the level of advance payment on a monthly basis. These amounts will no longer form part of the "scale of fees" determined under subsection 40AA(6), but will be included in calculation of the "notional scale of fees" determined under section 46D of the Act.

The amendments to sections 40AD, 40ADA and 51A of the Act are consequential to the above simplification measures. These amendments will preserve the right of a nursing home proprietor to seek a "merits review" of the decision as to how much Commonwealth benefit is advanced under section 51A. An aggrieved nursing home proprietor will continue to be able to seek the referral of an appeal, to the Nursing Homes Fees Review Committee of Inquiry, of a decision on the level of Commonwealth benefit paid under section 51A. The retention of a right of "merits review" is essential to ensure that unnecessary and costly appeals to the courts are circumvented.
The second concern is addressed by a series of minor amendments that relate to nursing homes which have been granted "exempt bed status".

Recent newspaper reports, relating to the compliance of nursing homes with the standards made under section 45D of the Act, have highlighted an anomaly in the current legislation. The anomaly is that the current provisions of the Act do not enable the revocation or suspension of "exempt bed status" for those nursing homes which have failed to satisfy the standards for nursing home care. The anomaly must be immediately addressed and the amendments contained in the Bill will overcome this concern.

The granting of "exempt bed status" under section 39AB of the Act enables a proprietor to charge additional fees to nursing home patients. One of the criteria for granting "exempt bed status" is that the nursing home provides a higher level of accommodation and services than are normally available at a nursing home. It is clearly incongruous to continue to allow a nursing home to charge additional amounts for a supposed increased level of accommodation and services, when the level of nursing and personal care fails to meet the basic standards.

The amendments contained in this Bill provide the power to suspend or revoke the "exempt bed status" of a nursing home where there is a declaration in force, under subsection 45E(1), that the nursing home does not satisfy the standards determined under section 45D of the Act. The amendments make it clear that while the "exempt bed status" of a nursing home is suspended, or revoked, a proprietor will be unable to charge the increased level of fees that would otherwise be payable by the nursing homes' patients.

It should be noted that the exercise of this new power will only occur where there are serious breaches of the section 45D standards. The decision to suspend the "exempt bed status" of a nursing home will be made where there is some prospect of the standards being reached within a short period of time and where both the nursing home proprietor and management show a commitment to taking remedial action.

The decision to revoke the "exempt bed status" of a nursing home will be made where the nursing home proprietor or management fail to show a commitment to taking appropriate action within a reasonable timeframe. Where there is little prospect of the standards being reached within a reasonable period of time, then the current power, in section 44 of the Act, will be used to revoke the approval of the nursing home altogether.
The decision to suspend or revoke "exempt bed status" is to be subject to internal review, as well as review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The proposed amendment to the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992 is to specify directly the Health Ministers to be consulted by the Minister before appointing the Chairperson of the Council, the Chairperson of the Australian Health Ethics Committee, a Principal Committee of the Council, and the member of the Australian Health Ethics Committee classified as a person with knowledge of the ethics of medical research. Currently the Act provides that the Minister is to consult in relation to these appointments with the other members of the Australian Health Ministers Conference. The composition of that membership can of course vary from time to time and currently includes the New Zealand Minister for Health. The proposed amendment would specify that it is the Health Minister of each State and Territory who is to be consulted in relation to the appointments.

I now turn to the amendments made to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. One of the principal purposes of these amendments is to establish the basis for a new accelerated process for placing listable drugs supplied in Australia on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods and to provide better definition to some poorly understood aspects of the National Regulatory Scheme for Therapeutic Goods which have been identified in it's first four years of operation. A mechanism to address shortages, or the absence, of essential drugs required by the public in emergency situations has also been included in the bill. Amendments that update and consolidate the entry, search and warrant powers in a new part to the Act have also been included, together with changes to align the monetary penalties in the current legislation with the "penalty units" classifications used in other Commonwealth regulatory legislation. The bill also closes a gap in the current regulatory scheme by which illegal therapeutic goods of unknown quality, safety or efficacy, are at present not able to be removed from the market.

Other amendments in the bill include a provision to replace the Therapeutic Goods Administration Trust Account with the Therapeutic Goods Administration Reserve, consistent with changes to be made by the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1995 and related bills that will replace the Audit Act 1901. The appeal provisions in the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 relating to the review of decisions to register therapeutic goods have also been tightened. This is intended to ensure that technical and scientific data sought to be relied upon in connection with a general marketing application will be properly evaluated before a review on merits is undertaken by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

One of the success stories of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 has been the orderly transfer of listable products—vitamin and minerals, homoeopathic, herbal and sunscreen preparations above SPF4—into the National Regulatory Scheme for Therapeutic Goods. Since the commencement of the legislation on 15 February 1991 some 14,000 listed drug products have been placed on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, and are currently being added to at the rate of some 2,000 per annum. This very strong demand for listing new products on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, reflects the keen interest in the community in having access to safe and well manufactured alternative medicines and the expectation is that the present very high level of product applications will continue.

The impact on the Therapeutic Goods Administration of the very high number of product applications has been substantial, with the average approval times for individual products averaging five months—well in excess of the initial target of thirty days. To address this problem, the Government provided $.775M in the 1994-95 Budget for the development of a new streamline process for listing products on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods which would cut product approval time to a matter of weeks, without in any way affecting the quality or safety of the medicinal products. The new process makes absolutely no changes to the policy on listed products, but does provide a fully automated document lodgement and assessment process, which will be available to industry from 1 July 1995. The new electronic lodgement facility and all supporting documentation has been developed through a steering committee with membership drawn from the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the three affected industry organisations, and the Consumer Health Forum.

The new accelerated listing process continues the premarket assessment of applications which is one of the central planks of the national regulatory scheme. Responsibility for making the assessment will be vested in the applicant who will be able to undertake the assessment against published criteria and documentation and submit an application in a form which is electronically compatible with the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods data base. Applications are to be accompanied by a certificate that the goods are eligible for listing, are safe for the purposes for which they are to be used, their presentation is acceptable, they conform to standards and have been manufactured by an appropriately licensed manufacturer in Australia. Goods which are manufactured outside Australia will still require TGA approval of the manufacturer before a listing application can be made.

Lodgement of an electronic application under the accelerated listing process is expected to be able to reduce the timeframe for product approval from an average of five months to approximately two weeks. Subsequent to the approval, the TGA will carry out a 100% audit of product eligibility, both in terms of formulations and claims made and will subsequently undertake a random audit of applications which are lodged annually for listing on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. The accelerated listing process will meet the requirements of industry for certainty in terms of product launches, whilst maintaining the existing high level of surveillance of product quality and safety. In the event that the TGA surveillance demonstrates that certification by a sponsor was false, then provision is included in the bill for cancellation to be immediate on any safety related issues, but in other circumstances, for example less serious label errors, sponsors would have the opportunity to make a submission before any decision is taken to proceed to cancel the product. Any decision by the TGA to cancel the product listing is subject to appeal to the Minister and to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

A new provision, section 19A, has been included in the Act to provide the Government with the means to deal with acute shortages of drugs supplied in Australia or that no longer are supplied here by their sponsors, or to temporarily allow into the Australian market a drug that is not available in Australia but is required to address an emergency. The Act as it stands allows individual patients to access unapproved drugs in limited circumstances. This entails prescribers to gain individual permission for each patient from Canberra, or for a prescriber to seek the status of an authorised prescriber under the Special Access Scheme.

Although both of these schemes are used with advantage to permit the supply of small volumes of unregistered drugs, they are too unwieldy and too slow to make available substitute drugs, or new drugs, on a larger scale to meet an unforeseen emergency or to permit interim supply of a product registered overseas during the period of evaluation in Australia.
There are a number of reasons why approval may be sought and granted for supply of drugs under this provision.

For example a company may find itself out of stock of a particular product and wish to supply the same product as registered in the United States or Canada. Recently, there has been a shortage in Australia of lithium drugs used in the treatment of mental illness. It has proved very difficult to obtain a substitute product from an overseas source because of the requirement to have the product registered prior to supply in Australia. Companies who have the product have been understandably unwilling to go to the trouble and expense of registration as a stop-gap measure.

Although vast improvements have been made in the approval time for new drugs in Australia, it remains inevitable that companies will register their drugs in America or Europe prior to introduction into Australia and that Australian patients and their doctors may have to wait until a company applies to register a drug in Australia. Provided that an application is in place in Australia and that the

drug is deemed to have a unique therapeutic potential by the Therapeutic Goods Administration it is proposed to permit limited supply on the basis of one or more overseas approvals. In this context, Australia has a number of arrangements in place for the interchange of information with reputable drug regulatory agencies around the world. These include the United States, Canada, Sweden, the United Kingdom and New Zealand. Through its membership of the PER (Pharmaceutical Evaluation Reports) Scheme, Australia is in a position to deal with most European agencies and with South Africa.

The emergence of new diseases, new treatments and medical emergencies may mandate the supply of unregistered medicines as an emergency measure. Such an occasion might be the need to immunise a large number of people against a tropical disease with a vaccine held in insufficient quantities in Australia. If such a vaccine is not registered in Australia, supply is presently cumbersome requiring individual approval from Canberra.

The safety measures to be put in place will include resorting to temporary approval under section 19A when no registered substitute product is available. Furthermore, delegations under this section are to be limited to the National Manager of the Therapeutic Goods Administration and the Head of the Drug Safety and Evaluation Branch.

Restrictions and conditions relating to the supply of such substitute products may be imposed to ensure that this provision cannot be used to avoid the process of drug evaluation and registration in Australia.

The interface between food and drugs has been a source of considerable confusion since the commencement of the Therapeutic Goods Act in 1991. The existing definition of "therapeutic good", excludes "food" but in the absence of a definition of what constituted "food", claims have been made for example that:-

PARA.TAB: Skin treatment products that "nourish" the skin are a food and therefore not a therapeutic good,
Gelatine is a food therefore products (including drugs), in gelatine capsules are not therapeutic goods.

SPEECH.PARA: These examples demonstrate the legal complexity involved in enforcement action through the courts, in the absence of a clear definition of what constitutes a food for the purposes of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989.

Detailed discussions have been held between representatives of the National Food Authority, the Therapeutic Goods Administration, State and Territory health agencies, and with the food and pharmaceutical industries, aimed at clarifying the food/drug interface. The outcome of these negotiations was agreement to introduce a definition of "food" into the Therapeutic Goods Act, which made it quite clear that decisions on what constituted a food or a therapeutic good was closely linked to its presentation and promotion and that a food could not be restricted by any specific dosage limit. The words "prescribed dose" and "frequency of administration" have been included in the definition of "food" and are to be read in a pharmaceutical sense, and is not intended to encompass serving suggestions applied to or normally associated with food and beverages.

The existing legislation has an anomaly in that it contains provision for a product to be removed from the market if it is cancelled from the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, but has no similar provision for removing from the market illegal therapeutic goods that were never included in the Register, whose quality, safety and efficacy are unknown. When such products are detected, and action is taken against sponsors, there is no existing basis whereby those products can be removed from the market, pending either prosecution or submission of an application to the Therapeutic Goods Administration for inclusion of the product on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. Provision has therefore been included in the bill to enable the Secretary to require persons to take steps to recover from the market any illegal therapeutic goods, or to inform the public in a specified manner and within a reasonable timeframe, that the product has not been reviewed for quality, safety or efficacy by the Therapeutic Goods Administration. Decisions of the Secretary in this matter are appealable to the Minister and to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The bill also proposes to redraft the main offence provision in the legislation, which currently provides that offences of import, export, manufacture or supply of goods in Australia are committed by a person who is the sponsor of therapeutic goods. The definition of sponsor does not however include a person who exports, imports, manufactures or arranges for the export, import or manufacture of goods on behalf of another person who is a resident of, or carrying on business in Australia. The effect of the current provision is that TGA must undertake intrusive investigations into the business affairs of persons that still fail to establish who the sponsor of the goods is, precluding any proceedings from being instituted to deter or prevent the unlawful supply of unapproved and sometimes dangerous therapeutic goods.

The bill proposes to clear away the need for such investigations into matters that can best be established by those in possession of facts best known to themselves, the sponsors, by establishing that the offence of import, export, manufacture or supply of goods in Australia for use in humans is committed by a person, and by including a statutory defence for the person to demonstrate that he was not the sponsor of the goods at the time the offence was committed. This arrangement will protect the innocent agent from prosecution, and remove from the TGA the requirement to undertake extensive investigations into the business affairs of persons who are simply acting as the agents for product sponsors.

The Act currently contains provisions for entry, search, inspection, sampling and seizure in relation to premises of sponsors, manufacturers and other premises for the purpose of monitoring compliance with the Act, ensuring compliance with standards (GMP audits and post market surveillance) and gathering evidence of offences committed against the Act. These provisions are restricted to authorised persons, are provided for both with and without warrant and are spread across a number of sections and subsections contained within parts 3 (sponsors), 4 (manufacturers) and 6 (any premises) of the Act. The bill proposes to consolidate these provisions into a new Part 5A entitled "Entry, Searches and Warrants", the existing powers have been reviewed and the provisions have been re-drafted to bring them into line with the current legal policy cited in part 1AA of the Crimes Act 1914, which was inserted by the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994.

The bill now makes it quite clear that entry without warrant to the premises of sponsors and manufacturers, cannot be exercised at residential premises unless the sponsor or manufacturer uses the premises for commercial purposes in relation to therapeutic goods as well as a residence. The bill also introduces a power of entry to enable authorised persons to enter premises where it is necessary to do so in the interests of public health so as to avoid an imminent risk of death, serious illness or serious injury. This provision is sought to enable, for example, the prevention of extremely dangerous products from entering the market (in the case say, of toxic contamination); or the halting of dangerous manufacturing process (in the case say, of a clandestine laboratory utilising volatile chemicals).

The bill also proposes that a number of indictable offence provisions in the Act be reduced to summary offences. Since the inception of the Act, experience has shown that these matters can be more appropriately dealt with by a court of summary jurisdiction rather than through the much more lengthy trial process. This change will convenience both the Crown and the accused as well as the judicial system.
The Act currently contains forfeiture upon conviction provisions in relation to illicit goods. This provision currently applies only to summary
offences. The bill proposes that the illicit goods, the subject of indictable conviction, also be forfeitable.
The amendments detailed in this bill largely address process and safety

PARA.TAB: the process by which drug products supplied in Australia are listed on the ARTG, as well as providing a basis for distinguishing between foods and drug products, and
safety, in providing a mechanism to remove products of unknown quality, safety and efficacy from the market.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill also reviews, and consolidates the enforcement provisions under the Therapeutic Goods Act, and brings them into line with the most recent Commonwealth policy in this area. As such the bill will substantially assist the sponsors of listable drug products in getting good quality and well manufactured medicines onto the market in a short timeframe, whilst improving the ability of the Therapeutic Goods Administration to protect the Australian public from sub standard, unsafe or ineffective products.

Other changes included in the bill are provisions to replace the Therapeutic Goods Administration Trust Account with a new Reserve Account, consistent with changes to be effected by the new financial management package, including the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1995 that will replace the Audit Act 1901. Section 45 of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 will establish a Therapeutic Goods Administration Reserve and make provision for the annual appropriation of monies into the Reserve equal to the receipts identified under that section.

Changes to the appeals procedure for the review of decisions to register or not register therapeutic goods under section 25 of the Act have also been included in item 148. These changes are designed to encourage applicants for general marketing of registrable therapeutic goods to provide all relevant scientific and technical data to the Secretary before a decision on registration is made under section 25 of the Act and to ensure that any new technical and scientific material not previously before the Secretary will undergo proper evaluation before a decision on review based upon merits is made by the administrative appeals tribunal.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

(3) In approving the export of woodchips derived from forestry operations in National Estate areas, the Minister for Resources followed the procedures set out in Section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. These analyses addressed the nature of the proposal, the effect of forestry operations on National Estate places, whether there were feasible and prudent alternatives, including the adverse effects on industry of not permitting forestry operations in National Estate areas and the adverse environmental impacts of providing contractual timber requirements only from non-National Estate areas. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Taxation: Living Away from Home Allowance

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the taxation of the living-away-from-home allowance (LAFHA):
(1) How is it proposed that the value of the benefit provided to employees which is not in the form of cash will be evaluated for group certificate purposes.

(2) If a LAFHA is paid to an employee which is initially excluded from income tax and fringe benefits tax and ultimately it appears that the employee has lived away from home for greater than 12 months would it be expected that group certificates previously issued would have been amended.

(3) In the construction industry, most construction jobs take longer than 12 months to complete, if that construction site is in a remote area and the employee works on that site for more than 12 months returning home to the family for regular rest and recreation, would this be considered to be a taxable LAFHA.
(4) How is it proposed to ascribe a value to someone living in a construction camp.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Since the introduction of Fringe Benefits Tax in 1986, where an employee: (a) receives a living-away-from-home allowance; (b) is reimbursed for accommodation expenses while living away from his or her usual place of residence; or (c) is provided accommodation while living away from his or her usual place of residence; it is the employer who is liable to pay tax on the benefit. No amount is included on the employee's group certificate.

Similarly, where an employee who is not living away from his or her usual place of residence (as determined by the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986) is reimbursed for accommodation or is provided accommodation, it is again the employer who is liable to pay tax on the benefit. No amount is included on the employee's group certificate.

An employee will only be liable to pay tax on this type of benefit where the employee is not living away from his or her usual place of residence and is paid a cash allowance. In some circumstances, the employee may claim a deduction against the taxable allowance. If an amount is to be included on the employee's group certificate, the amount to be included is the amount of the cash allowance.

(2) If the LAFHA is bona fide, that is, if at the time the employee first receives the LAFHA it is intended (as evidenced by the employer and employee declarations) that the period that the employee is to live away from home is to be 12 months or less, then there will be no need to amend any previously issued employee group certificate. This is because the employee will only be liable to pay tax on the allowance from the end of the 12 months or from the time it is known that the period will extend beyond 12 months, whichever is the earlier.

(3) Under the proposed changes, a cash allowance paid to an employee working at a remote area construction site for a period in excess of 12 months would be taxable in the hands of the employee. However, I am aware of the concerns expressed by some about this result and I am currently considering a number of submissions on this matter.

(4) As indicated in my answer to Question (1), there is no need to ascribe values for accommodation provided in construction camps. This is because the value does not have to be included on a group certificate.
